newsitem.title: USA: End USDA 'finality rule'--Senate farm panel chair.
newsitem.headline: End USDA 'finality rule'--Senate farm panel chair.

text.p: The "finality rule" that allows farmers to keep overpayments from the U.S. Agriculture Department would end under a bill introduced in the Senate, Agriculture Committee chairman Richard Lugar said Tuesday.

Lugar, an Indiana Republican, said the regulation was not needed under the "Freedom to Farm" law. The rule let farmers keep inadvertent overpayments on crop subsidies or disaster payments if USDA did not ask for reimbursement within 90 days.
The rule cost $4.2 million from late 1990-September 1996.
In the past, Lugar said, farmers often relied on USDA determinations in deciding which crops to plant and the acreage for each.

"Under the 1996 farm bill, farm payments are no longer linked to the planting decisions of farmers," Lugar said in a statement. "Today, payments are based on a formula that does not vary from one year to another."
A General Accounting Office report said 86 percent of finality rule cases involved differences of $500 or less.

Lugar also filed a bill to put USDA's chief information officer clearly in charge of computer purchases. The bill gives the officer yes-or-no power over purchases and control over part of each agency's budget as a way to control purchases.
